text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to hold a summit meeting in Libya today. Information Minister Safwat el-Sherif said Mubarak's visit would last two days.

- Mubarak reviews peace-saving efforts and Egypt's contacts to activate the Palestinian track of talks with Israel. The president's political adviser Osama al-Baz will hold two meetings today with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat. Based on the outcome of the two meetings, a tripartite meeting will be decided.
- The General Federation of Egypt's Labour Unions condemns the Turkish aggression against northern Iraq.
- Police killed three terrorists in the province of Minya, 240 km (150 miles) south of Cairo, in a gunbattle early yesterday.
- The cabinet decides to increase cash allocations for farmers' wheat deliveries to 700 million pounds ($200 million).

- Interior Minister Hassan el-Alfi said: "The next confrontation of security authorities will be with the (outlawed Moslem) Brotherhood, if it tries, directly or indirectly, to impose itself through crooked means." Alfi told a gathering of university academics: "The security authorities will not allow the Moslem Brotherhood to run for the next elections at the press and lawyers syndicates."
- Mubarak to chair the second meeting of the higher council for exports in July.
